question: Question_01_(b)
statement:
In this question we will work with polynomials of degree 3 written

\[\displaystyle
p(x) = a_1x^3 + a_2x^2 + a_3x + a_4\]

\textbf{(b)} Show that \emph{dim(N(A)) = 2} and bind a basis
\textbf{a}\textsubscript{1}, \textbf{a}\textsubscript{2} for
\emph{N(A)}.
sols:
In
\href{Science:Math Exam Resources/Courses/MATH307/December 2012/Question 01 (a)}{part
(a)} we found that

\[A=\begin{bmatrix}
12&4&1&0 \\ 
0& 0&1&0
\end{bmatrix}\]

The matrix \emph{A} has 2 pivot columns and so by rank-nullity theorem

\[\displaystyle{}\dim(N(A))=4-\dim(R(A))=4-2=2\]

and so there are two basis vectors for the nullspace. To find them we
could row reduce \emph{A} or notice that, at \emph{x = 0},

\[\displaystyle{}3a_{1}(0)^2+2a_2(0)+a_3=0\]

gives $a_3=0$. Using the value at \emph{x=2}

\[\displaystyle{}12a_1+4a_2+a_3=12a_1+4a_2=0,\]

gives $a_2=-3a_1$. Since neither equation depends on $a_4$ then it is a
free variable. Hence, the basis of \emph{N(A)} is

$\vec{a}=\begin{bmatrix}
a_1\\ 
a_2\\ 
a_3\\ 
a_4
\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}
a_1\\ 
-3a_1\\ 
0\\ 
a_4
\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}
1\\ 
-3\\ 
0\\ 
0
\end{bmatrix}a_1+\begin{bmatrix}
0\\ 
0\\ 
0\\ 
1
\end{bmatrix}a_4$

Hence, $\vec{a_1}=\begin{bmatrix}
1\\ 
-3\\ 
0\\ 
0
\end{bmatrix},\vec{a_2}=\begin{bmatrix}
0\\ 
0\\ 
0\\ 
1
\end{bmatrix}$
hints:
How does the dimension of the nullspace relate to the number of pivot
columns of the matrix?
Recall we can find the nullspace by row-reducing.
